I was 14 when I convinced my dad to go to the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta, the next morning,  I watched him die on TV.

My mother Spencer, left my father in 1968 when I was only a few days old. The final straw was when he came home one night especially drunk. My father, Nick, was a full-blown alcoholic by this point, but this night was different; he became physical. My father took me from my mother and forcefully threw her out of the house.

She was 2 weeks out of the hospital from my birth and still had stitches in her stomach. My father and I were locked inside alone, and all my mother could do was watch us through the windows. He stumbled about the house with me in his arms, eventually passing out. My mother was able to get back into the house. She grabbed me, and a couple changes of clothing and left my father. My parents were divorced shortly after, and I’d only see my father a few times in the next 8 years.

In 1976 when I was 8 years old, my dad wrote me a letter. He wanted to re-connect with me. He was living in Arizona where he owned an insurance company. Not long after receiving his letter, my dad let me know he was driving to Albuquerque to see me. I’ll never forget the day. I stood out at the corner down the street from our house at the southwest corner of Los Alamos and Laguna, so I could see him coming.

He was supposed to arrive at 2:00 pm. I remember vividly looking into every car that passed by for my dad. At 8:00 pm, well after dark, my grandmother Marion “Bama” Cornish walked down the street, put her arm around me, and held me tight as she walked me home; not a word was said.

I fell asleep that night crying with my pillow over my head, so nobody could hear me. I still can’t forget the feeling of being worthless, my own father had forgotten about me. He never did show that spring, and I didn’t see him for a very along time after that.

My dad’s life was intense. He was born to William Anton Rank and Mary Collaer. William’s father, my great-grandfather, was partners with and a cousin of Conrad Hilton, of Hilton Hotels. He was partners with Conrad in the startup of the Hilton Hotel chain.

My grandfather William was killed in a mugging in El Paso, Texas when my father was a child. As a result of my grandfathers’ murder, which went unsolved, my father inherited my grandfathers’ hotel fortune at an early age. My father enjoyed his inherited money and lived the life of a jet setter. However, this fortune was probably one of the worst things that could have happened to him.

He was drawn to Hollywood, where he produced music and television. None of it was very successful, other than one song that made the charts. In all reality, my dad was just another young, good looking rich kid, who eventually was chewed up and spit out by Tinseltown. He wasn’t cut out for swimming with the sharks. He left for Arizona to rebuild his life.

I eventually reconnected with my father after he’d move to Colorado and began going to spend time with him twice a year. This was absolutely an amazing time for me. My life in New Mexico was wonderful, but also chaotic and confusing; I had bounced from home to home, until I settled at my grandparents.

But twice a year, I was with my “dad”, he was great and we had a ton of fun; he could do no wrong in my eyes. I was never with him long enough to see his character defects, his human side. I just saw the man who was always excited to see me, was new and exhilarating, and lived a life that I desperately wanted to be a part of.

When I was thirteen, my grandparents let me know that my dad was moving back to New Mexico. They told me that he’d checked himself into a treatment center and when he got out, he’d permanently live in Albuquerque. I was ecstatic. I spent the next month fantasizing about how good my life was going to be with my dad home. My dad lived up to absolutely every expectation I had for him. His first-year home was an amazing, and to this day, it was the best 12 months of my life.

My father had remarried for the 4^(th) time, and his new wife “PJ”, was an extremely cool and beautiful woman. We had so much fun together. She had a great sense of humor, which made her a perfect stepmother for me.

My dad was working part time at a law firm, and part time as a disk jockey at a local FM country radio station. I used to love to go down to the station with my dad and just watch him work. He had a wonderful deep voice and always said cool stuff. One night, I went down to the station with my stepmother to hang out with dad. He was pretty busy on air, so PJ and I started exploring the radio station.

We found another broadcast booth and started pretending to be disk jockeys. We were singing into the microphone and saying the silliest things. PJ really got into it and was acting like a complete clown. Partway through her silly skit, I decided to play a joke on her. I gave her an incredibly shocked look. She stopped her routine and asked what was wrong. I mouthed, “the microphone is on, you’re broadcasting, over my dad!” Well PJ absolutely fell for it and freaked out.

PJ went tearing down the hallway to my father’s broadcast booth. He was on the air, live as PJ slid into the room. She was mouthing, “I’m sorry, I’m sorry, I’m sorry” over and over. My dad, headsets on, cigarette in his hand, microphone to his lips, talking to 100,000 people over the airways, gave PJ the funniest look I’d ever seen. I was behind PJ in the hallway bent over laughing, snot coming out of my nose. My dad shifted his confused look from PJ to me. The look on his face went from confusion to a wonderful grin and obvious understanding of the situation.

Dad signed off by saying “This is Nick Brainard at KRST; I’ll see you all tomorrow night.” He flipped the switch in the microphone, spun around in his seat and started to laugh. A deep beautiful laugh.

PJ was still trying to explain that she’d drowned out his broadcast with the silly skit in the next room. She was convinced that she’d been talking and singing to all the listeners out there in Albuquerque, and she was mortified. My dad of course knew this wasn’t true, and that I’d played one hell of a trick on PJ. His laugh went from his chest to his belly, a deep cheerful laugh. PJ was a great sport about my joke, but I did have to watch my back for weeks after. She never did get me back.

Although my father and PJ were not drinking anymore, they smoked lots of marijuana. My great grandmother who we called “Granny”, was the president of the New Mexico African Violet Society. She had a huge green room at my her house that was filled with flowers. Granny would help my dad grow his pot. The two of them would start the plants in her greenhouse under the grow lights. Then, they’d transplant the marijuana into the back yard amongst the various garden bushes and trees. I was fourteen, it was 1982 and I loved to swipe off my dad’s pot plants and get stoned. I’m sure he knew but never said anything.

By the fall of 1982, I was starting my freshman year in high school and my dad’s new wife was pregnant. It was a happy time. For the first time in my life, I felt completely secure. It was also time for the Albuquerque International Balloon Fiesta. This event draws up to 500 + hot air balloons; it’s amazing. Since PJ was new to Albuquerque, and had never seen it, my dad decided we needed to take her the next morning.

That evening, I got a call from a really cute girl I’d met at the beach in La Jolla, California earlier in the summer. Her name was Erin, she had blonde hair, and I had a huge crush on her. Erin was in Albuquerque for a couple of days and wanted to go to a movie with me the next day. Of course, there was no way that I was going to the balloon fiesta now! I was an Albuquerque native and had already seen it. But a blond cute girl asking me out on a date, well that just doesn’t happen every day, and my hormones weren’t going allow me to pass up this opportunity!

As my dad and PJ got ready to go home for the night, I told them that I couldn’t go to the fiesta the next day. My dad told me that was fine and they’d decided to go up to the top of the mountains to watch it from there. The Sandia Mountains tower over Albuquerque. There is a spot at the top where you can look down at the entire city. I was surprised that my father wanted to take PJ up there, for her first Balloon Fiesta experience. It was a long drive and would be nothing like being at the launch site.

I was adamant that they not go to the mountains. I told him that PJ would have a much better time, walking through the balloons as they inflated and launched. It is a breathtaking event to be a part of. I persisted until my dad finally relented and promised to take PJ to the fiesta instead of the mountains.

The next morning, I awoke early; I was excited to go on my date. Granny and I where the only ones in the house. Both my grandparents and parents had decided to go to the balloon fiesta. Granny and I were talking about my date with the cute blond from the beach, while we ate breakfast. She wanted to know all about the girl and what we were going to do. Of course, as my words told her about going to a movie, but my hormones were imagining kissing!

The television was on; live scenes of the balloon fiesta were coming in over the airwaves. As we were talking, a “breaking news” broadcast came blaring out of the television. The reporter announced that there had been a balloon crash, and the following scenes were not suitable for children.

The screen jumped to a very large balloon whose’ gondola was filled with passengers. As the balloon did a hard landing, we could see somebody jump, out as if something was wrong. Flames appeared and the balloon shot back into the air. Several more people jumped out, the quick drop in weight caused the balloon to ascend rapidly. By this point, both the gondola and balloon were on fire.

As the balloon reached a substantial altitude, there were a series of explosions, and a lot of fire rolling in every direction. I sat there with Granny, our attention fixated on what we were watching. Another large explosion, followed by two people falling from the balloon. These people were holding onto each other as they fell to their death. Smoke following their bodies as they plummeted to the earth. The impact was brutal, and there was no doubt that they could not have survived that fall.

It was a terrible scene; we’d just watched 2 people fall to a gruesome death, and there was no doubt that other passengers had died as well. People were scurrying all over the place trying to help. The camera would occasionally focus back in on the balloon, which was engulfed in flames and disappearing over the horizon. Until my dying day, I’ll never forget Granny, without taking her eyes off the TV screen saying, “I sure do feel sorry for the families of those people.”

A short time later, a neighborhood friend came over to hang out with me. We went out into the back yard, talked about the balloon wreck that he’d also watched on TV, and started throwing the football. Partway through passing the ball, my friend glanced into the house. From the back yard, you could see the street in front of the house, through a large window. His jaw dropped wide open, he turned back to me and said, that a police are here. I froze; I knew that they were there because of my dad’s marijuana plants. Before I could say a word, my friend ran and jumped over the back wall. I ran through the house and got to the front door, just as the policeman knocked.

When I opened the door, there was a policeman in a suit and two uniformed officers. I thought I could see my father and PJ standing out in the street, their backs to me. The police came in and to my surprise, didn’t say a thing about the pot plants. They told Granny and me that there had been a terrible wreck involving Mr. and Mrs. Brainard. The policeman didn’t say that they were dead; he just said, “terrible wreck.” Granny, being the wise old soul she was, looked the officer in the eye and said, “are they dead.” There was a long pause while the policeman stared at me. He then looked back to Granny and whispered “yes.”

Granny sat there with her hands over her face, crying. The policeman gently rubbed her back and tried his best to comfort her. I was still standing there stunned, my grandparents had been killed. I’d never experienced anything like this before. I had no way to process what had just happened. I stood there frozen, trying to make sense of it all. How did it happen, where was the car wreck, why did it happen?

After a few moments, I looked outside towards where I thought my dad and PJ were. I needed my dad right now; I needed to hold him. I ran past the police officer and out the front door towards them. Just as I ran out the front door, another car pulled up into the driveway. As I ran, I looked over to see my grandparents pulling up. They were alive. I stopped cold in my tracks. I could see the wide-eyed look on their faces, as they took in the scene taking place in the front yard of their house.

I was shocked, I’d just been told that they were in a wreck and were dead. I was trying to comprehend what was happening, did the police have the wrong family?

I turned my head back towards my dad and PJ. They were no longer looking away from the house, they were looking towards me, and they were not my dad and PJ, they were two more police officers dressed in civilian clothes.

In an instant, my world came crashing down around me. Everything went into slow motion. I couldn’t stand; my legs didn’t work. I fell to the ground. I watched the young police officer run across the yard to intercept my grandparents. I could see my grandmother’s face grimaced with agony as she was told that her oldest son was dead, the officer had to help her sit down; she too couldn’t stand. Then my grandfather, the toughest man I’d known in my life, started sobbing like a child. His upper body draped over the hood of the car, hands over his head, moaning. It was an absolutely horrible scene.

I clearly understood now that there was no car wreck, this had nothing to do with a car. My dad and PJ, were the two people we’d watched being blown out of the balloon, falling to their death, together. I’d just watched my father pregnant stepmother die a horrible death. I’d watched the whole thing, not knowing it was two people who I dearly loved. Granny had said that she felt sorry for the family of those people, and it turned out that we were those people.

I went into a deep shock, that lasted for a long time. To make matters worse, I got a little lost in the confusion. My father was so popular and loved, not only in the family, but in the community. People were flooding to the house, and everybody was beside themselves with grief. I can remember sitting in the corner, no able to move, not able to cry, not able to do anything, but sit there, stunned.

At one point, my aunt Beth noticed me sitting by myself in the corner. She walked up to me, rubbed my head, and said that she had just the thing to make me feel better. She handed me a joint. This was such a common solution to problems with my family, inebriation.

During this ordeal, the person who really touched my heart, and allowed me to grieve in the days following their deaths, was my uncle Dar. I was sitting in my father’s van. It had just been towed back from the Balloon Fiesta parking lot. I’d been sitting there for a couple hours. It smelled like my dad and PJ, so there was nowhere else on the face of this earth that I wanted to be.

Dar came out to check on me. He opened the door and asked me if there was anything I wanted. I said, “I just want them back.” Dar grabbed onto me, and we both started crying. It was really the first time I’d broken down since their death. I’ll always be grateful to my uncle Dar for that moment. I believe in my heart it’s what I needed to survive.

The next few weeks were a nightmare. All the television stations kept replaying the scene; we didn’t dare turn on the TV. People were coming and going, and there seemed no time to decompress and grieve. Then I watched as people started to come and take my father’s things, right in front of me. I don’t think the thought even crossed their minds, that my father’s and PJ’s belongings should go to their children. It was awful.

Their personal belongings were being carted off, as if we were having a free yard sale. People who had little to do with my father, helped themselves to his belongings. As I write this today, I still have a tough time keeping my resentment in check for these individuals. I wish I still had every item of my fathers. The few that remained, my brother and I have cherished, as if they were the Hope Diamond; they’re irreplaceable to us. I’ve often wondered if anything was given to PJ’s daughter. I’ve been reconnected to her for a few years now, but never had the courage to ask.

During the period that the looting of my father’s belongings took place, and the constant stream of people flowing through the house, I found the perfect coping mechanism: alcohol. My grandparents’ house always had booze here and there, but now it was overflowing. People were bringing liquor by the gallons, and nobody was paying close attention to me.

I would grab my usual cup of 7-UP, add wine to it, put the headsets over my ears to drown out the sounds, and play the Dan Fogelberg greatest hits 8 track. This would take me away from it all, it did the trick. This was the beginning of a long and brutal battle with alcohol and drug addiction for me, but I’ll save that story for another time.

It came time for my father’s funeral, and this too was a terrible experience. There were so many people, and I only knew a few of them. I can remember during the service, I was up near the casket, I looked into the audience, and there were two girls I went to school with: Kerry and Tanya. I was so grateful to see their faces, two friendly faces that I knew, and liked very much. I’ve been forever grateful for their presence.

When they put my father’s body in the ground, I couldn’t believe what I was seeing. I’d just been with him at the radio station having fun. He’d just let me drive on the road without my license! We’d just sat in his cool green van and listened to music with PJ. This couldn’t be happening. I couldn’t go back to my old life! He couldn’t leave! And that’s when it hit me; I’d talked my father into going to the balloon fiesta instead of the mountains.

The realization that I’d killed them spread throughout my body. All these people watching his body being lowered into the ground, mourning this tragic loss, and it was because of me. I couldn’t look anybody in the eye. I just stood there staring at my father’s casket. I desperately wanted to touch his coffin and say goodbye, but I couldn’t bring myself to move. To this day I still regret not walking over and touching his coffin.

The level of guilt that I carried for the next twenty years was absolutely brutal. No fourteen- year-old should ever have to shoulder this kind of responsibility. It warped my life in the most incomprehensible ways. I feel incredibly fortunate to have survived.

>>83096547
I don't smoke or use delta-whatever products, so it doesn't affect me much there. I do think that there is plenty of promise in cannabinoids for managing various health conditions. I have used various CBD/CBG/etc products, and they have helped with inflammation in my body as well as wound healing and somewhat with stress. On the more psychoactive side of things, I have only used a handful of lighter 10mg edibles before. They were mostly pleasant, but I didn't dive that deeply into them.

I know that plenty of people become dependent on it to blunt reality, including two friends of mine who both quit using it entirely because of that. My perspective is that government over-regulation, much like prohibition, only serves to promote grey and criminal markets, harming consumer availability of safe/healthy goods and reducing consumer agency of choice. As with most substances in its class, the consumer should be responsible, not any government agency. I don't think it ultimately serves the consumers/patients or research well to continue adding restriction after restriction, and ironically, there probably won't be much of a financial incentive either since they won't make sales/license fees on it.

>>33899030
A little more nuanced but mostly correct. Nurses find a lot of fulfillment in areas like LDRP and pediatrics. General floor nursing can be a shit show. Psych units often have primarily addicts and ex-convicts and the few people that actually are helped never show up again.

That said there are a lot of positives. Scheduling can be awesome (e.g., 3 day workweek full-time). Nurses can change specialties rather easily. There are huge advancement opportunities. Lots of nurses go into administration, education, or advanced practice after getting a bit of experience. As an example, my hospital paid for my MSN in full and is covering most of NP school which I'm doing while I work. Money is good and it is a career field that is resistant to technological capture.

Desperate for help. Climate change makes me want to end things

Hey everyone.
Before you ask, yes, I’m in therapy, and yes, I’ve just started anxiety medication. I’m not looking for debate or denial, just honest perspective from people who get it.

I tried to post in other environmental subreddits but it wouldn't let me. 

I know all the good facts. I really do. Things like:

Global emissions have plateaued and are starting to edge down in key regions.

Over 90% of new electricity capacity worldwide is renewable.

Renewables are now the cheapest source of new energy in most of the world.

EV adoption is skyrocketing, and some projections suggest 80% of new car sales could be electric by 2035.

Even oil companies are being forced by investors and markets to decarbonize.

Big tech companies are chasing real net-zero targets, and public pressure is forcing them to.

Carbon capture and removal projects are scaling up fast, with multiple plants now operating and many more being built.

Major reforestation and soil carbon projects are quietly expanding across continents.

Methane leaks are finally being tracked and cut at scale.

Public awareness and policy momentum are miles ahead of where they were even five years ago.


I know all this, and I believe it means things are changing.
But emotionally, I can’t seem to catch up.

I grieve for the coral reefs, the forests, the lives already being lost to extreme weather. I don’t know how to hold the pain of it without drowning in it. I keep thinking, “Sure, maybe we’ll fix things, but I don’t want to live through the growing pains.”

It’s not that I think the world is ending. It’s that I don’t know how to exist in one that’s so visibly struggling.

If you’ve felt this too, how do you live with it? How do you make peace with the grief and still live your life? Is there anything I’ve missed or any other hopeful projections that you hold on to? Cuz it's getting harder to want to live in a world this painful. I can't handle this constant, growing grief for everyone and everything. 

Thanks for reading. I just needed to get this out.

Mi madre me decepcionó al tener una relación con mi mejor amigo… y años después la vida me permitió devolverle la misma moneda:

No sé por dónde empezar. Si estás leyendo esto, quiero que sepas que no hay peor traición que la de la persona que te dio la vida y del amigo en quien más confiabas.  
  
Me llamo Cesar, y esta es la historia de cómo mi madre traicionó mi confianza al involucrarse con mi mejor amigo… y cómo, años después, el karma se encargó de hacer justicia.  
  
Desde pequeño fui un chico tranquilo, el menor de tres hermanos. Tenía una relación muy cercana con mi madre, Fernanda: una mujer fuerte, trabajadora y hermosa. Ella sola nos sacó adelante desde que mi padre falleció en un accidente de motocicleta cuando yo tenía apenas cinco años.  
  
Mi madre siempre fue una mujer atractiva: cabello rubio, cuerpo delgado y una energía que llamaba la atención. Pero para mí, era simplemente mi mamá.  
  
Todo cambió cuando conocí a Alex, quien con el tiempo se convirtió en mi mejor amigo. Nos unían los videojuegos, el básquetbol, el fútbol, las motocicletas y la música.  
  
Recuerdo cuando lo presenté en casa. Fernanda lo miró con esa mezcla de curiosidad y simpatía que no supe interpretar en ese momento. A partir de entonces, comenzó a mostrar un interés especial por él… un interés que, en su momento, confundí con simple amabilidad.  
  
Con el paso de los meses, Alex se volvió casi parte de la familia. Mi madre lo trataba con una calidez que me hacía sentir un poco desplazado, aunque intentaba no darle importancia. Pensaba que simplemente se llevaba bien con él.  
  
Un día, regresé a casa antes de lo previsto. Al subir las escaleras, escuché risas y sonidos que jamás hubiera querido oír. Abrí la puerta de la habitación de mi madre… y allí estaban. Ella y Alex.  
  
Sentí que el mundo se me derrumbaba. No podía respirar. No podía creer que mi madre y mi mejor amigo me estuvieran haciendo eso.  
  
No hice escándalo. Solo regresé a mi cuarto, tomé una mochila, metí mis cosas y algo de dinero en efectivo. Cuando volví a la habitación de mi madre, ellos aún estaban allí. Les dije con voz temblorosa: “Si eres feliz con él, está bien, mamá. Pero no cuentes más conmigo.”  
  
Salí de la casa sin mirar atrás.  
  
Me refugié en casa de mi tío Carlos, el hermano de mi difunto padre. Él me recibió con los brazos abiertos. Me apoyó en todo y me ofreció un techo hasta que pudiera independizarme. Bloqueé a mi madre y a Alex de todas mis redes y números.  
  
Pasaron los años. Supe por mis hermanos que mi madre y Alex siguieron juntos y hasta se casaron. Yo, por mi parte, me dediqué a estudiar ingeniería en informática, conseguí trabajo como desarrollador y me enfoqué en crecer profesionalmente. Gracias a mi esfuerzo, obtuve una beca para continuar mis estudios en España.  
  
Madrid fue el comienzo de una nueva etapa. Trabajé, estudié, y poco a poco sané mis heridas. Pero el destino aún tenía preparado un giro inesperado.  
  
En una conferencia de informática conocí a Mariana, una mujer inteligente, elegante y llena de vida. Al conversar, descubrí algo sorprendente: ella era la mejor amiga de mi madre, aunque hacía años que no se veían. Al principio me desconcertó, pero con el tiempo, su compañía me ayudó a cerrar heridas.  
  
Salimos varias veces. Tenía una energía que me hacía sentir en paz. Con ella, recuperé las ganas de vivir. Una noche, durante una cena, me atreví a contarle todo: lo de mi madre, lo de Alex, lo que sentí. Mariana me escuchó en silencio, y al final me abrazó con ternura. Fue el primer abrazo sincero que sentí en mucho tiempo.  
  
Con el paso de los meses, Mariana y yo nos enamoramos. Formamos una relación sólida basada en confianza y respeto. No era venganza; era amor. Mis hermanos, aunque al principio dudaron, terminaron apoyándome.  
  
Pasaron seis años desde mi llegada a España. Me gradué, fundé mi propia empresa de tecnología y me casé con Mariana. Ella me apoyó en todo y juntos tuvimos un hijo precioso llamado Jeff. Sentía que, por fin, la vida me había recompensado.  
  
Pero el pasado volvió.  
  
Una de las ferias tecnológicas a las que debía asistir se celebraría en Los Ángeles, la ciudad donde crecí. Decidí ir con Mariana y nuestro bebé. Durante el evento, entre los asistentes, reconocí rostros familiares: mi madre y Alex. Con ellos, una niña pequeña.  
  
Fernanda estaba irreconocible: envejecida, con la mirada cansada. Alex también lucía derrotado.  
  
Cuando se me acercaron, ella murmuró con voz temblorosa: “¿Cesar… hijo, eres tú?” No respondí. En ese momento, Mariana se acercó con Jeff en brazos.  
  
—Amor, aquí estás —dijo con una sonrisa, mientras me abrazaba frente a mi madre.  
  
Fernanda se quedó helada. —¿Mariana? ¿Tú y Cesar? —preguntó sin poder creerlo.  
  
—Así es —le respondí—. Mariana es mi esposa… y este es nuestro hijo.  
  
Alex bajó la mirada. Mi madre no pudo pronunciar palabra. Mariana solo sonrió con serenidad, esa sonrisa de quien sabe que la vida hace justicia por sí sola.  
  
No fue venganza. Fue justicia poética.  
  
La vida se encargó de poner a cada quien en su lugar.  
  
Hoy no guardo rencor. Espero poder perdonar a mi madre algún día, reconocer sus errores y aceptar que, aunque nos separó la traición, también fue quien me enseñó a ser fuerte.  
  
Ahora tengo mi propia familia, y cuando los miro, entiendo que a veces el dolor más grande es el que nos moldea para convertirnos en mejores personas.  
  
¿Ustedes qué harían en mi lugar? ¿Perdonarían? Sus consejos son bienvenidos.

**Perspectiva De Fernanda.**

*No puedo describir lo que sentí cuando lo vi. Aquel joven que estaba frente a mí no era el mismo muchacho al que lastimé años atrás. Era un hombre hecho y derecho, exitoso, sereno… y con la mirada de alguien que ya no me guarda rencor, sino distancia.*

*Mi voz tembló al pronunciar su nombre: “¿Cesar… hijo, eres tú?”*

*Y cuando ella se acercó —Mariana, mi mejor amiga, la hermana que la vida me dio y que perdí por mis propias decisiones— sentí cómo se me apagaba el alma. Llevaba en brazos a un bebé hermoso, de ojos brillantes y sonrisa dulce. Cuando escuché a mi hijo decir que eran su esposa y su hijo… fue como si el tiempo se detuviera.*

*El corazón me dolía. No por celos, ni por sorpresa… sino porque entendí, en un solo instante, todo el dolor que le causé.*

*Ahora era yo quien veía cómo la persona que más amaba formaba su felicidad lejos de mí. Él tenía lo que yo le arrebaté años atrás: una familia verdadera, una mujer que lo amaba, un hogar que no dependía de nadie más.*

*En ese momento, comprendí cómo se había sentido cuando me vio con Alex. Entendí su rabia, su decepción y su silencio. No hacía falta que dijera nada: su mirada lo decía todo.*

*Vi a Alex junto a mí, cabizbajo, con el peso de la culpa en los ojos. También vi a nuestra hija —la niña inocente que no tiene culpa de mis errores— aferrada a su mano. Pero mi propio hijo, Cesar, apenas la miró. Su atención estaba en Mariana y en su pequeño. Y lo entendí.*

*Él ya había elegido su vida. Una vida sin mí.*

*Por dentro, sentí una mezcla de tristeza y alivio. Tristeza porque perdí a mi hijo, y alivio porque al menos lo vi feliz, completo, amado. Tal vez el destino quiso que Mariana apareciera en su camino no para herirme… sino para mostrarme lo que destruí por no saber valorar el amor verdadero.*

*Ahora sé que el karma existe, y no como castigo, sino como una lección silenciosa. Lo que un día hice, la vida me lo mostró desde el otro lado. Y no lo digo con rencor, sino con aceptación.*

*Si pudiera retroceder el tiempo, abrazaría a ese joven de corazón roto y le diría que lo siento.*

*Que nunca quise quitarle la paz, que solo fui una mujer confundida tratando de llenar un vacío.*

*Y aunque tal vez ya sea tarde, solo espero que algún día mi hijo pueda perdonarme, aunque sea en silencio. Porque su perdón sería el único consuelo que me queda antes de partir de este mundo.*

**Actualización Final:**

Han pasado varios años desde aquel encuentro en Los Ángeles. 

Desde entonces, muchas cosas cambiaron en mi vida… y también dentro de mí.

Durante mucho tiempo pensé que el silencio era la mejor forma de sanar, pero entendí que el verdadero cierre no llega cuando olvidas, sino cuando te atreves a enfrentar el pasado sin rencor.

Hace unos meses recibí una carta de mi madre, Fernanda. 

No buscaba excusas ni justificaciones; solo quería verme.

Decía que necesitaba hablar conmigo antes de que fuera demasiado tarde, mirarme a los ojos y pedirme perdón. 

No sabía qué hacer. Pero Mariana me miró con esa calma suya y me dijo:

—Ve, César. A veces el perdón no es para los demás… sino para uno mismo.

Tenía razón. Así que tomamos un vuelo de regreso a California.

Cuando llegué, mi madre me esperaba en el jardín de la casa donde crecí. 

Se veía más frágil, con el rostro marcado por el paso del tiempo, pero había una paz en su mirada que no recordaba haber visto antes.

A su lado estaba Alex, el hombre que alguna vez fue mi mejor amigo y después mi mayor herida.

Y frente a ellos, una niña ya mayor —mi hermana— jugaba entre las flores, riendo sin entender todo lo que ese reencuentro significaba.

Nos miramos por unos segundos que parecieron eternos.

Luego di un paso al frente y simplemente dije:

—Hola, mamá.

Ella me abrazó con fuerza.

Y en ese abrazo, sentí cómo se disolvían años de rabia y resentimiento. 

No hubo discursos ni explicaciones, solo lágrimas.

A veces el perdón no necesita palabras; solo presencia.

Más tarde, Mariana llegó con nuestro hijo Jeff. 

Al verla, mi madre se emocionó y la abrazó con un cariño sincero.

—Gracias por cuidar de mi hijo cuando yo no supe hacerlo —le dijo.

Mariana sonrió y respondió:

—Gracias por traerlo al mundo.

Alex se acercó después.

Lo miré a los ojos, y por primera vez en muchos años, no vi culpa ni arrogancia.

Solo sinceridad.

—César… de verdad, lo siento.

Yo asentí. 

No necesitaba escuchar más. En ese momento comprendí que el perdón era más para mí que para ellos.

Pasamos la tarde conversando, riendo un poco y recordando lo que alguna vez fuimos.  
Vi a mi madre y a Alex tomados de la mano.

A pesar de los años y de que ya no pueden tener más hijos, se notaba que habían encontrado una especie de felicidad tranquila, una paz que llega cuando aprendes a vivir con tus errores y seguir adelante.

Y fue ahí, en medio de esa calma, cuando Mariana me tomó de la mano y me susurró algo que me dejó sin palabras:

—Amor… tengo que decirte algo. Estoy embarazada.

Me quedé inmóvil unos segundos.

—¿De verdad?

Ella asintió, con los ojos llenos de lágrimas.

—Cuatro meses. Es una niña.

Miré a mi madre, que también lloraba, y en ese instante entendí que la vida había cerrado su propio círculo: una historia que comenzó con dolor y terminó con una nueva oportunidad de amor y familia.

Nos quedamos todos allí, viendo a los niños jugar y a Mariana acariciar su vientre.

Sentí que mi conciencia, por fin, estaba en paz.

El pasado había dejado de doler.

Acepté a mi hermana como parte de mi familia, y mi madre aceptó a Mariana, a Jeff y a la pequeña que viene en camino.

Ya no había culpas. Solo gratitud.

Cuando me despedí esa noche, mi madre me abrazó y me dijo entre lágrimas:

—Gracias por dejarme volver a ser tu mamá.

Y yo le respondí:

—Gracias por dejarme volver a ser tu hijo.

Hoy, mientras grabo esto, siento que todo terminó donde debía terminar: en el perdón. 

No fue venganza ni justicia poética.

Fue **reconciliación**.

Anxiety ruined a very important trip for me - How can i get past this heartbreak?

# [](https://www.reddit.com/r/mentalhealth/?f=flair_name%3A%22Need%20Support%22)Hi!

Writing this because today feels worst than usual.

To give a bit of background, I started having anxiety issues after developing Dp/Dr ( still don't know why it came in the first place) when I was 13. It then took years of panic attacks, medications, until now, 23 I had finally reached a place where I felt like that could never happen again. I thought i had faced all my fears and it would never bother me.

Cut to a month ago. I decided to visit my long distance gf. She lives in the Us and me in Europe. Within the second day, everything came back. I hadn't had dissociation or a panic attack is 8 years and i've travelled a lot in those years, but it just came back in an instant.

It's now been a month, and we've had some good days, pretty memories, fun moments, but's its also been 60% of being absolutely miserable.

She's had to take care of me constantly, I even bursted in tears on her birthday after pushing myself to do all of stuff and trying to hide my anxiety all day.

I feel so bad for her. I'm also really grieving what I imagined this trip to be.

I leave in today and I just have so much guilt, regret, anger. I ruined this trip for myself and her.

i won't see her for months.

I'm exhausted, completely dissociated, lost, scared. I feel like I ruined everything.

I have been struggling for a while and just don't know what to do

Hello! I have had anxiety for a very very long time, ever since I was a little kid, specifically agoraphobia, dp/dr, panic disorder and what not. I was able to stay afloat by just burying them all down and pretending they didn't exist until about 2 or 3 years ago, I had an extreme breakdown and my agoraphobia went berserk for almost a year. I could barely leave my own bed without having panic attacks and it was extremely difficult.

During that time I met this person who helped me a lot through all of this and they were kinda like my safety net, they knew very well what it is I was going through and was able to teach me to manage it so well. After a while I started to get much better, and I was able to go out and be around people for long periods of time and I felt like I was starting to return to some sort of normality. But about 3 or 4 weeks ago, me and this person had an extreme falling out, it was really messy and we have basically cut contact with eachother, and since then I have absolutely spiraled. I have constant panic attacks daily, I have trouble sleeping, I feel extremely depressed and alone. I still try to go for walks every day but I can barely leave further than a few meters from my house before I feel unsafe and need to go back.

All of this just boils down to me feeling extremely unsafe. I feel like when I have panic attacks, I have no one to rely on if things go sour. I have a ton of amazing people who are always here to support me and help me when I am in need, but I feel so extremely disconnected from all of them. I feel like they don't truly understand what it is I'm going through and I just can't feel any sort of security in them, even tho I rationally know that I can find the help I need in them.

I just feel so alone, despite having people in my life that are willing to help me. I am trying to take things one step at a time and let myself feel my emotions. But I am just so extremely tired of always dealing with panic attacks. I just want to see some light at the end of this tunnel, but I just feel so hopeless. I have gone through this before and I know I will get through it again. But I am just so tired.

Thank you so much for reading this. I have been trying to post and talk about this kind of stuff with people who maybe understand my condition, find some people who know what it's like and maybe find some comfort in it. I really wish you all the best, and I know how awful these things can be. I hope at least someone can find comfort in knowing they are not alone if they are going through something like me <3

I lost myself trying to be enough for everyone… but I’m learning to live again.

I don’t know where to start. Maybe from the beginning — from a little girl who was born into a family that probably didn’t need her. When I was born, everyone seemed happy at first, but that warmth faded fast. I was mostly raised by my grandmother because my mom was young and had her own struggles.

I grew up watching fights, feeling unseen, and constantly trying to earn love that should’ve been freely given. For me, education became everything — my only way to prove I mattered. I was a excellent student till grade 5,But in 6th grade, I failed to meet expectations for the first time. I scored 11/25 in Math and 13/25 in Hindi. That day, I faced the kind of fear that changes a child. I was beaten and shamed — and I remember crying not because of the marks, but because I felt I wasn’t enough.

From then on, fear became my biggest motivator. I was the “smart” kid who slowly turned into an “average” one. I pushed myself through every grade, terrified of failing again. By the time I reached high school, I was exhausted — emotionally and mentally. I still remember my 10th board results: 92.1%. People said it was good, but to my parents, it wasn’t good enough.

I worked so hard to prove myself — joined a good college, studied day and night, but lost my determination and joy. I was constantly compared to others, reminded of my flaws, and never allowed to just be me. I lost myself, and somewhere along the way, I stopped feeling happy.

Then came the pandemic — lockdowns, isolation, online classes. My 12th didn’t go as planned, my medical entrance didn’t work out, and I felt like a failure. My parents compared me to others again, and I remember thinking, I just want to disappear.

But I didn’t. I got into engineering that too good college, built projects, and tried to find some sense of purpose. I worked hard, sometimes too hard. Still, life had other plans. I faced setbacks — I even failed one subject and couldn’t bring myself to tell anyone. The shame nearly broke me.This time my hair fall problem had started but I couldn’t give attention to it.

Later, I got an internship even with my backlog and then a full-time job. On paper, I was doing fine. But inside, I was drowning. My parents became stricter, and I was juggling work, home responsibilities, and endless expectations. I felt like a robot — waking up, working 10–12 hours, coming home, and doing house chores. No rest. No peace.

Then came another blow — I started losing more hair due to stress and thyroid issues. Watching handfuls of my hair fall out every day shattered me. I lost my confidence, my smile, and my will to look in the mirror. I felt ugly and worthless.

There were days I questioned why I was even alive. I cursed myself for being born. I had no dreams left, no confidence, no reason to keep going.

But somehow, I did.

Because maybe… life isn’t about being perfect. Maybe it’s about surviving through imperfection.

I realized that even if I don’t have much to show, I still have something to give — kindness, love, empathy. I still live because I want to make my mom proud someday. I still live so that I can help my sister chase her dreams. I still live so that some other girl who feels like giving up can see this and know she’s not alone.

Even if I’ve lost everything, I haven’t lost the power to try again.

So here I am — not “healed,” not “successful,” but still here. Still learning. Still choosing to live.

If you’re reading this and feel like life has broken you — please hold on. You don’t have to shine right now. Just survive. That’s enough. One day, you’ll look back and realize surviving was your biggest victory.

Thank you for reading — this is the story of a girl who’s still learning to love herself. ❤️

I can’t let go of someone who says she only wants to be my best friend


I (32F) fell for my colleague (30F) last year. We got close through work, she used to mention me to all her friends, told me she dreamt about me, and before long, we were spending nearly every day together. What started as friendship turned into something deeper. I was her first relationship with a woman, and for a few months, it felt real and mutual.

Then, she ended it over text, on my birthday. She said a same-sex relationship wouldn’t work, that she wasn’t a lesbian. I was heartbroken. But even after the breakup, neither of us really let go. It turned into this painful situationship she wanted closeness and comfort, but not commitment.

Today, after two years, I finally gave her belongings back things she left at my place months ago. When I handed them to her, she started crying. She said she’s scared I’ll cut her off, but also repeated that she “can’t be more than a best friend” to me because she’s not a lesbian. I told her I understood, but inside I was breaking. Because I can’t be just her best friend. I still love her.

I’ve muted her on all social media and I’m trying to move on, but I feel empty. It’s like she gets to live freely and move forward (she has met a new guy) while I’m stuck processing the wreckage. She said she was selfish for keeping me around knowing she cannot give me more. I keep replaying everything how she used to confide in me, depend on me, and how she’s now giving parts of that to someone else.

Right now, I’m trying to accept that she only wanted the parts of me that made her feel safe not the whole of me. And that’s not love.

I know I need to let go completely. I just wish it didn’t hurt this much to lose not only someone I loved, but my best friend too.

I want to move on. I want to be free. But part of me is still waiting for her to miss me the way I miss her.

I don’t know whether to stay friends, create distance, or cut contact completely. I still care deeply about her, but I also know she’ll never choose me.

The problem is, I struggled with severe depression over the past three years, and unfortunately, I was only able to receive proper treatment quite late due to various reasons. This had a huge impact on my life — I went from being one of the top students to barely passing.
During that time, I couldn’t bring myself to study properly, which led to poor results in almost every exam and a lot of wasted time. I also couldn’t get any extra tutoring or academic help because I had already fallen behind in my studies.

And now, I’m trying to relearn all the subjects I couldn’t learn before, while also keeping up with the new topics. Tbh, it’s all became a huge mess. Since I’m still dealing with depression, I can’t study properly, and the stress just keeps making things worse.

I'm 26 and I've been diagnosed with depression since I was 13. For half of my life I've had this heavy, aching weight inside of my chest. I've been a looming mist in other people's lives, filling the empty air with half-hearted plans and unkept promises. 

I'm in tens of thousands in debt from student loans and no degree to show for it. I've dropped out/taken leaves on and off since finishing my first semester of college, all for mental health reasons: eating disorder, alcoholism. Upon my most recent return (after a 5 year hiatus) I was really determined to finally finish what I started. This year felt like *the one*. I finally left an abusive 4-year relationship, I reassessed my priorities, and I started doing what's best for me. Then, after my first week of classes I was drugged, kidnapped, and raped by my coworker who is twice my age. Boom. Back to square one, again. Now I am out of a job and on another leave from school, waiting for a break in my case because my rapist is nowhere to be found. What the fuck do I do? I can't cope anymore. 

I just can't to do it. I don't want to keep trying, the more I try the more I feel myself digging deeper into a hole of debt and doubt for nothing. I feel like a sham and a waste. I see my older sister with her master's degree and 6-figure job, I see my cousin in his microbiology PhD program, I see all my college friends with their degrees, newer friends with established jobs, and it all hurts that I can't be that. I'm lost. I'm indecisive. I'm incapable. I've job hopped around 8 jobs in the past 5 years, I can't settle and I can't just be content. I never finish what I start. I'm stuck in this rut, the same rut I've been in since before I can even remember. I don't trust myself to pick a path that is right for me anymore. I keep hitting walls instead of finding a door and I want to give up trying so I can at least get used to the disappointment. 

This is my daily spiral. Today, it is especially overwhelming.

Don’t know how to understand

I met this girl on Reddit a while back. It started as a casual, friendly chat, nothing serious, just random conversations we were just doing  casual chats Slowly, we got into a small rhythm. We barely talked over calls( but she talks shares more over a call) but we did connect sometimes.

One day, she sent me a picture covering her face, and damn, it looked nice in dress. I complimented her and teased her a little, just for fun. Our chats were always light and friendly, but somehow, I enjoyed those little talks.

Earlier, she used to reply quite fast, but after she moved to another city, her replies became slower. Still, I remember those days when she was in her hometown — she’d share her cooking pics, small snaps, and random things she made. Honestly, those small things made my day. I don’t know why, but they did.

We never met in person, barely talked on calls, but she used to send me her photos, singing clips, dancing videos… little pieces of her life. Those small moments genuinely made my day. I don’t know why, but I felt happy just seeing her happy.

I never had any big expectations from her. I just liked her presence in my life  even if it was rare and unpredictable. She used to talk generally, casual chats and all but she always kept sending those snaps. It made me feel like I mattered to her in some small way.


Now I’m left confused.
If she didn’t care… why did she make me feel like she did?
Why show me that little closeness if there was never any intention to stay?
What if she already has someone? Why involve me then?

I know she was never mine… but it still hurts to feel replaced without even knowing what went wrong.

Just wanted to get this off my chest.

We talk about Mental Health, but we still glorify overworking. Isn’t that hypocrisy?

You ever notice how everyone keeps saying “take care of your mental health”, but the moment you slow down, people start calling you lazy?

I see this every single day. People posting about self-care, therapy, and balance, and then bragging about how they slept only 4 hours, worked 10 straight days, and “still showed up.” Like, isn’t that the exact opposite of what mental health actually means?

We’ve turned exhaustion into a badge of honor.
We wear stress like it’s a medal.
And if you try to take a break, society makes you feel guilty, as if resting means you’ve failed.

It’s funny and sad at the same time, we talk about “burnout culture,” yet we secretly admire the ones burning out the fastest. Maybe we’ve confused being busy with being valuable.

I’m not trying to sound preachy. I’ve been there too, overworking, forcing productivity just to feel worthy. But now I’m trying to unlearn that. To slow down. To live without feeling the need to prove something every day.

Hello! I’ll try to sum this up briefly, I’ve been having this issue for the past 6 or so months. Some context, I have had severe generalized anxiety since I was pretty young and one of the strange side effects of this is that I constantly hyper ventilate and feel like I’m unable to catch my breath. I’ve gotten this checked out by pulmonologists and they’ve all said it’s purely psychosomatic. This issue has also caused me very bad chest and back pain due to constantly breathing heavily which has worsened in the past year.  I also want to be clear because doctors seem to misunderstand me when I talk about this, but this issue a constant thing and doesn’t only occur during panic attacks. This is also something a large amount of my family members have experienced who also have anxiety, but mine is the most severe from what I gather. There hasn’t been one moment since 11 years old that I haven’t been manually breathing/forcing in air. Starting about 6 months ago I have woken up every morning with stabbing pain in my chest and abdomen that make me feel as if an elephant was sleeping on me all night. I thought for awhile that it may be heart burn but I’ve experienced heart burn before and it’s nothing like it. I do not have the best diet and use strong nicotine pouches but I am a healthy weight for my age , I just wanted to include this because I’m still open to the idea that it may be diet related. I also have an appointment for a sleep study  coming up soon to rule out sleep apnea.

Multiple gods cannot be omnipotent, omnipresent, and omniscient at the same time, primarily because the concept of omnipotence is a logical contradiction if shared. I don’t know what to do

I made this account for the purpose of making a post like this. I just don’t know what to do. Very long story short I am a first responder and I think my job causes or at least exacerbates the vast majority of my mental health struggles. I have been doing this job for about 6 years (not a long time, I know) but I feel like it is absolutely destroying me. No matter what I do it seems like I always get something wrong. Every response has some major point that I have a personal issue with and I like many first responders am very critical of myself. I am well aware of this and I know I should “give myself grace” but that mantra doesn’t take away the feelings I have no matter how much I try to believe it. I was recently promoted and many people around me tell me that I am worthy of this promotion and that I do a very good job. I just can see past the outward praise and I know for a fact that I am not what they think I am despite whatever appearance I put on. Every single shift I have horrible anxiety and constantly think about quitting and what life could be like without this job. The problem is that every family member and friend I have think that quitting would be the most absurd idea ever and they refuse to even see it as a possibility. About a year ago I went and got some professional help and was diagnosed with MDD and social anxiety. This came after I decided that the amount of drinking to self medicate that I was doing was a problem and additionally at the time I was having persistent thoughts of self harm. I was in-patient for 38 days and I find myself almost wishing I was back in that environment because I was heard. I also was not working during that time which probably also helped. I just feel so absolutely trapped by this career that I am utterly drained and have difficulty finding any enjoyment in life. I can’t imagine doing this for 20+ more years because I am miserable and I don’t see things turning around when this job constantly beats me down. I feel sick just thinking about it. It seems like there could be so much more to life if I could have even one day that I can say I truly enjoyed. Even my days off are ruined by the mere thought that I have to return to work at some point. I just want out before too much irreparable damage is done. I can’t stand it much longer.

I truly am meant to be alone. Hello. I'm not looking for advice or success stories. I just want to hear from people who can relate.

I have depression and I've been on treatment since 2022. I've tried so many medication and none of it was lastingly effective. I feel like I'm rotting on the inside and a husk of a human being on the outside, forcing myself to keep up with life. I don't feel like I'm living. I'm just depleting every remaining ounce of strength in me to pretend to be functional: I wake up with immense dread, shower, endure my cattle-transport like commute, show up for work that I absolutely hate, buy microwaveables because I lost my passion to cook and to nourish myself. I’m a teenager and I saved my nephew from choking, but his parents acted like it was nothing

I’m a teenager and just need to get this off my chest. This happened recently, and I still feel uneasy about it.

We were watching a movie — me, my mom (his grandma), and my two nephews. Their parents (my sister and her husband) were in the kitchen.

We were eating mandarins when suddenly my 4-year-old nephew started choking. He grabbed me, pinched me, and pointed at his mouth. I didn’t understand at first, but then realized he was choking and couldn’t breathe.

I immediately started patting his back, but it didn’t help, so I flipped him upside down and shook him gently — and the piece of mandarin flew out.

He started crying a bit, but then calmed down, and we went back to watching the movie.

Later I told my sister and her husband, but they reacted so calmly — just said, “Well, he choked, but he’s fine now, right?”

Their reaction really shocked me. Why would they act like that? I can’t stop thinking about it.

Birthday Self Sabotage

So my birthday is coming up, and I the waves of anxiety (and also sadness) have begun. I know it’s completely understandable to cry or be sad on your birthday but I just don’t know how to get past this. 

Last year on my birthday, my family planned a lovely dinner and I was an hour and a half late for it because all I could do was sit on the floor and cry. I couldn’t even articulate to my husband why I was crying, I got snappy and short (he sat with me the whole way bless him) and at each moment, I knew I exactly what I was doing but just could not make myself stop. 

This year is my 30th, and I’ve accomplished so much, logically I know I have. But I just can’t stop sinking into the sadness and panic feeling. My husband has tried to plan a birthday lunch with my loved ones but I just can’t stop sabotaging -  I tell myself that people love me and that they want to do this for me, and then insist he cancels. I make excuses that it’s Sunday, and most people would rather stay in. That I’ll be tired because we have a wedding the night before, or that I won’t want to clean my home after hosting.
It got to a point where yesterday he just said he’s cancel the whole thing, and then I immediately felt incredibly guilty. 
The worst part is that I’m so aware I’m sabotaging I just can’t stop doing it. 

I don’t know what else to do. Does anyone else get this way? How do you manage this? Any advice  would be so appreciated.

It does gets better❤️

I’ve had a really intense year. “Crazy” doesn’t even begin to describe it, but I think I’m finally starting to heal a little.

Late last year, I was physically assaulted by my partner. Even though deep down I knew things weren’t right, I couldn’t walk away. I loved her, and a part of me still cares about the version of her that I believed in. After the assault, I was told not to say anything to my doctors or the police because it could get her in trouble. I kept quiet for a while, trying to protect her, even though I was the one who needed help.

Things got worse in March. I don’t remember everything clearly, but after a bad argument, I overdosed on my medication. I genuinely don’t know how I survived that night. I ended up detained in hospital, confused, lost, and barely able to make sense of what had happened. My memory from that time is still patchy, but what I do remember is feeling completely betrayed and broken.

When she found out the police were involved, she left the country. Later she came back and started spreading rumours about me, even filed a counter-complaint to try to paint herself as the victim. I realised then that maybe I wasn’t the one who had done something wrong; I had just been manipulated into thinking I was.

Since then, I’ve been fighting for accountability. I filed a small civil claim, not for money, but for truth. I wanted the court to hear what really happened. Things got messy, and there were attempts from both families to “settle it quietly,” even when I was in the hospital after another suicide attempt. But I refused. I didn’t want silence; I wanted justice.

Eventually, I applied for a non-molestation order and won. That gave me some protection, but more importantly, it gave me validation that I wasn’t imagining any of this.

In the past eight months, I’ve survived eight serious suicide attempts. Some of them left scars that will stay with me forever. I’ve been diagnosed with complex PTSD, and recovery has been far from easy. But I’m alive and that alone means I still have a chance to get my shit together and fight for myself.

If there’s one thing I’ve learned, it’s that it really does get better. Slowly, painfully, and sometimes with setbacks, but it does. I’m still working through it all the trauma, the legal fight, the memories but I’m also starting to rediscover life again.



If you’re in that dark place right now, please hold on. You’re not weak for breaking down. You’re not hopeless for struggling. You’ve just been through too much, and you deserve peace. I promise you, one day you’ll look back and realise you made it through things you never thought you’d survive. I did, somehow. And I’m still here. ❤️

I'm working a shitty job, failing at online college, have very few friends as they have moved on and living with my parents. It's so over bros.

This whole thing is fucking stupid, where it posits that non-suicidal people are "always happy". I'm not the least bit suicidal and I am definitely not happy all the time. Most people aren't. You should have different emotional responses to different experiences, and some of those experiences are negative. That is outside your control. The vast majority of people have negative experiences on a daily basis, to varying degrees, but the accumulation of these experiences over the course of their life has given them coping mechanisms to deal with emotions like disappointment, fear, anger, frustration, sadness, etc, so that the emotion is experienced and then moved on from. New experiences wash out bad experiences, and instead of permanently cataloguing every negative thing into permanent long term memory we learn to forget most of the details of our experiences, good and bad, and reserve long-term memory for only the most significant.

This is why a toddler will scream and cry because of disappointment over mommy not buying them candy at the supermarket, but a 20 year old realizing his bank balance won't allow him to buy everything he wants simply sighs and then figures out what he has to put back on the shelf. That same 20 year old might cry and be inconsolable after breaking up with his first girlfriend, or having his first family member die. The same man at 60 will have experienced more heartbreak, more death, and it will likely not consume as much of his emotional resources to move past each new person lost. It's not that he won't feel sad or bereft, he will simply be able to cope with it better.

Suicidal people simply don't know how to cope. They hyper-fixate on negative experiences, create delusional or unrealistic standards for happiness, and essentially make themselves miserable. There are people who exist in truly hopeless lives, people trapped in slavery for example, but the vast majority of suicides are not slaves. They're just moody little pricks.

People often say they will never do something even if the situation happens to them. I was firm believer in that, but I've become everything that I never wanted to be. If you read all of this, I'm sorry. 

I've never really had a bf my whole life, I've always been to myself, reserved, but also out-going. I never thought about drinking or partying, but I was never opposed to it. I just liked watching anime, drawing, working out and studying for the things that matter the most to me. My life literally changed when I met my bf. My 2nd year in college I had new roommates and one was by far the wildest (Christi). She introduced me to my  bf because he never lost his V-card. She wanted me to get to know him and see what happens. Little did they know, I was a virgin too. Long story short, my bf and I were pressured into having sex, but in the end, we started to date. 

In the beginning, I never thought about dating because I thought it would distract me from my degree and it did a little. Our relationship was great in the beginning, probably because I ignored every red flag known to man. Love makes you blind right? He is the sweetest, most loving and doting person I've ever met. He will always talk about you and things he wants to do with you. He'll plan cute dates and do things he doesn't like just to make you happy. Perfect guy right?

 I show up everyday. Not a single day late or absent. I got along with coworkers. I worked through lunch until I was told I needed to take one. (Hourly salary). I worked *fucking hard everyday* and asked for help and training. Each time I get blown off because everyone is so busy keeping their own head above water. 

My response to why I’m seeking another job without saying I got laid off: 

“Well, I decided to pivot towards a more research/output focused position and I needed more hands on training” aka I got sick of being a receptionist that got a random assortment of tasks to complete with no help or training. After I’d sit for an hour with an urgent question, I learned to stop asking and figure it out on your own. Only for them to penalize you for doing it wrong. You want initiative? Not that kind of initiative though. 

I’m fully aware of my weaknesses (customer interaction)… The ONLY roles available right now are retail and customer service based jobs. I am on the autism spectrum, I cannot work with people like that. I’ve said this so many times now I want to scream. No workplace is friendly towards neurodivergence, period. 

All entry level positions want you to have 2-5 years of goddamn experience and refuse to train, let alone give the kind of hands on training that I disclose to them in the interview that I NEED. 

I am sorry if this is an unstructured rant, I’m just so tired. I’m so frustrated. I’m broke, cavities in my teeth and no health insurance to fix it. I don’t want to work in a fucking Amazon factory bro. That’s the only option atp. It’s killing me. I don’t have a degree. I couldn’t afford it. I had no guidance growing up, nobody - including myself - ever had to foresight to say “stay in school or you’ll be miserable for the rest of your adult life”. All I have is about five years of retail/legal/reception experience, and maybe three jobs left I can apply to in this shit-hole city. There’s no tech companies or banks, data driven work to be found. There’s one major retailer and Amazon, some fast food joints. I’m not the type of personality that can do reception work. 

Nobody can keep me long enough to get my foot in the door “the old fashioned way”. I can’t do it anymore. I can’t take the embarrassment of losing another job, I can’t take the depression that follows from sitting at home alone all day. It’s going to kill me.

In this particular case I am indifferent, but the concern on leftist's part is the slippery slope that goes from oligopoly to monopoly. One company owning such a massive share of the media environment that a very small group of individuals can effectively control the socialization of citizens from infancy to old age is not good (at least from my perspective, let's not get into a debate about the meaning of good). Even if oligopolies don't necessarily reduce competition, I see having single entities with such a massive amount og influence as a bad thing. Massive national media conglomerates were essential in the rise of progressivism for instance, with progressive messaging being integrated thoroughly from childhood cartoons, to games, to teen shows, and then in all of the superhero slop for adults. Prednisone & Anxiety

Hi all! Long story short, I was prescribed prednisone (20mg tablets) to take twice a day this past Saturday after a mild allergic reaction. I started it with a double dosage on Saturday night, took one in the afternoon and one at night on Sunday, and one in the afternoon and one at night on Monday.

The issue is, Monday morning, I woke up feeling okay, but as I was driving to work, I felt anxiety hit me like a truck. I’ve dealt with mild anxiety before, but this was the worse I’ve ever felt before. My whole body was uncontrollably shaking, I was getting flush, I had this feeling of a lump in my throat. This intense episode lasted for about 2 hours before I was able to calm down, but even then, I was jittery and I still had that lump feeling.

Monday night I was a little jittery, but I didn’t have another episode like this and I was mostly able to sleep fine set aside waking up twice in the night.

After doing some research on prednisone, I decided to stop taking it after 3 days even though they gave me 5 days worth. 

Today, Tuesday, I woke up and felt ok. The lump feeling was a lot smaller, and the morning was fine. Right around 1pm though, my body started shaking, and I was freaking out. The lump feeling in my throat returned but felt even worse – I was coughing and dry heaving. I could still swallow water so I know my throat wasn’t closing, but I felt like it was going to. I was freaking out so much I considered calling into the ER, but I rode it out, and after about 2 hours, I was able to calm down.

Does anyone have any experience with this or how long it lasts? My last dose of prednisone was Monday night, and I didn’t except to still feel it on Tuesday. >>33849800
> When couples disagree about the degree of closeness and intimacy desired in a relationship, the issue eventually threatens to dominate all of their dialog. This is called the _anxious-avoidant trap_. The reason people in an anxious-avoidant relationship find it particularly hard to move toward more security is primarily because they are trapped in a cycle of exacerbating each other’s insecurities. People with an anxious attachment style cope with threats to the relationship by trying to get close to their partner. People who are avoidant have the opposite reaction. They cope with threats by taking measures to distance themselves from their partners. The closer the anxious person gets, the more distant the avoidant acts. One partner’s response reinforces the other’s in a vicious cycle, and they both remain within the relationship “danger zone.”

I feel like I’m slowly fading away

I don’t really know why I’m writing this here. Maybe because I have no one else to talk to, or maybe because I never really had anyone in the first place.

When I was eleven, I lost my mother, the only person who truly cared about me. My father is an alcoholic who used to treat her terribly, and I know that pain is what took her away. Since then, I’ve been living with my aunt, my mother’s sister. I call her “mom,” but it doesn’t feel real. Her affection often feels forced, like something she shows only when others are watching.

I barely have any real friends anymore. The few I had drifted away after I left my father’s home. The people I talk to online are distant too. They only speak to me in group chats, but never reach out otherwise. It feels like I’m invisible, like I could disappear and no one would notice.

On top of that, I face racism and religious jokes more often than I’d like to admit. I’m Black and Muslim, and somehow that’s enough for people to mock or judge me. Even some people I thought were my friends make jokes that cut deep, and then call it humor. It hurts, even when I try to act like it doesn’t.

Sometimes it feels like I don’t belong anywhere. My family is broken, my friendships are fading, and I’m just exhausted. I keep pretending I’m fine, but most days it feels like I’m just existing, not really living.

I’m not looking for sympathy or advice. I just needed to say this somewhere, because holding it in is starting to feel unbearable.

>>83161709
>but why would you want/ need to when they're incoherent? there is nothing to discuss.
We have been discussing incoherent ideologies. One can discuss the nature and propositions of "eat pray love," and point out inconsistencies, this does not mean it is not a philosophy or ideology.
>firstly, two critiques were made and they emphatically were critiques of pure reason and practical reason. you're seriously arguing that a critique of pure reason wasn't a critique of pure reason? amazing
It was not a critique of the core principles of enlightenment and not a critique of reason. You could have looked up the summary:
>The Critique of Pure Reason (German: Kritik der reinen Vernunft; 1781; second edition 1787) is a book by the German philosopher Immanuel Kant, in which the author seeks to determine the limits and scope of metaphysics.
This is not an argument against using reason by any means, and if you read it you would know that.
>>83161879
>this is what analytics think being counts as being reasonable
Yes, it is very reasonable. "It's false because it's self-evident" is not an argument. Language is not a self-evident phenomenon, unlike things such as
>I think.
This is self-evident because it could not be thought if it was not thought. Self-evidence can also be
>I see (something that appears to me as what I would call) red.
But self-evidence cannot tell you that two terms which are not contradictory:
>Ideology: a set of values and beliefs.
and
>Incoherence: The condition or quality of being incoherent.
There is no self-evidential aspect to say that a particular social construct cannot have contradicting terms. Reid does not make this argument either.

>how about you use your brain instead of looking for heckin' sources
This is not an argument. I am using my brain: An ideology can contain contradicting terms and thus be termed incoherent. It still exists as an incoherent ideology.
